vague_description: The taxi company faces a decision-making dilemma regarding the optimal mix of motorcycles and sedans to purchase in order to maximize earnings while adhering to pollution and transportation constraints.
detailed_description: A taxi company will purchase vehicles to rent to their drivers. They are interested in purchasing either motorcycles or sedans. A motorcycle can transport \param{MotorcycleCapacity} people, produces \param{MotorcyclePollution} units of pollution, and earns the taxi company \param{MotorcycleEarnings} per shift. A sedan can transport \param{SedanCapacity} people, produces \param{SedanPollution} units of pollution, and earns the company \param{SedanEarnings} per shift. Because not every customer is comfortable with a motorcycle, at most \param{MaxMotorcycleProportion} of vehicles can be motorcycles. Additionally, the company has committed to producing less than \param{MaxPollution} units of pollution. The company needs to transport at least \param{MinPeopleTransported} people every shift. How many of each type of vehicle should be used to maximize the total earnings for the taxi company per shift?
target_objective: Maximize the total earnings for the taxi company per shift
target_constraints: At most MaxMotorcycleProportion of the total number of vehicles can be motorcycles
The total pollution produced by all vehicles must be less than MaxPollution units
The company must be able to transport at least MinPeopleTransported people every shift
target_parameters: Number of people a motorcycle can transport per shift
Pollution units produced by one motorcycle per shift
Earnings from one motorcycle per shift
Number of people a sedan can transport per shift
Pollution units produced by one sedan per shift
Earnings from one sedan per shift
Maximum proportion of motorcycles in the vehicle fleet
Maximum pollution units the company can produce per shift
Minimum number of people the company needs to transport per shift
